author: morningstar.com
title: Samsung Introduces New Smartphone Running on Tizen Platform
text:
By Jonathan Cheng
SEOUL-- Samsung Electronics Co. isn't giving up on carving out an alternative to Google Inc.'s Android operating system.
On Wednesday, the South Korean technology giant introduced a new midrange smartphone in India that runs on its homegrown Tizen platform.
The new phone, called the Samsung Z3, is the company's second Tizen-powered smartphone, following the January release in India of the low-end Samsung Z1, which Samsung said Wednesday had sold more than one million units.
Samsung, the world's largest vendor of smartphones, relies on Android to power almost all of its smartphones. But it has long harbored hopes of building its own alternative operating system, which would give it more control over the software and services that consumers use on their devices.
However, it has struggled to convince third-party developers to rebuild their applications for Tizen smartphones, given the nascent operating system's still-negligible market share.
In recent months, Samsung has continued to plow ahead with Tizen anyway, embedding it in more the company's products.
In addition to the Samsung Z1 and Z3 smartphones, Samsung--the world's largest seller of televisions--said earlier this year that every one of its TVs would soon run Tizen, giving the operating system a boost thanks to Samsung's roughly one-third share of the global TV market.
And in September, Samsung unveiled the Gear S2 smartwatch, the latest in a string of wrist-mounted devices powered by Tizen.
But the biggest test for Samsung will come in the competitive smartphone market, where other aspiring smartphone platform builders like Microsoft Corp. and BlackBerry Ltd. have stumbled.
Part of the challenge for Samsung so far is that its Tizen smartphones now occupy the lowest end of the market. The first model, the Samsung Z1, is priced at less than $100 and aimed at first-time smartphone users.
In contrast, the new Samsung Z3 smartphone offers what the company calls "an upgraded user experience," with a 5-inch high-definition resolution display and an 8-megapixel camera--specifications that aren't a far cry from some of its midrange offerings in developed markets.
The phone is called the Samsung Z3 because it offers "a significant jump from the earlier Samsung Z1 in terms of specifications," according to Asim Warsi, a vice president for Samsung's India mobile business.
The new device will go on sale on Oct. 21 for 8,490 Indian rupees, or about $130, Samsung said.
The company said the phone was "designed specifically for the Indian market," and didn't disclose plans to sell it in other countries. After the Samsung Z1's launch in India in January, sales of the phone were extended to neighboring Bangladesh and Sri Lanka.
Write to Jonathan Cheng at jonathan.cheng@wsj.com
